A September climb up the third-tallest peak in Oregon, right in my backyard.

Living in Bend means South Sister is always on the horizon -- literally. At 10,358 feet, it's the third-tallest peak in Oregon and one of those hikes that locals talk about like a rite of passage. This September, I finally made the push to the top.

## The Route

I took the standard route from Green Lakes trailhead. That's the long way. It's 17.75 miles round trip with about 5,400 feet of elevation gain. Not technical, but relentless. The trail is well-marked through the forest for the first couple of miles, then breaks into open volcanic terrain that just goes up and up.

![The trail through the volcanic terrain](~/assets/images/hiking/south-sister-trail.jpg)

## The Climb

Started early to beat the afternoon weather. The lower section through the trees is pleasant enough, but the real work begins once you hit the moraine -- miles of loose volcanic scree where every step forward slides you half a step back. It's the kind of terrain that tests your patience as much as your legs.

Above the Lewis Glacier the air thins noticeably and the wind picks up. The final push to the summit ridge is steep and exposed, but you can see the crater lake below and the views start to open up in every direction.

![The scree field on the way up](~/assets/images/hiking/south-sister-climb.jpg)

## The Summit

Worth every step. From the top you can see the entire Cascade chain -- Broken Top right next door, Bachelor to the south, Jefferson and Hood to the north. The crater lake sits below the rim, still holding patches of ice even in September. It's one of those views that makes you just stand there and not say anything for a while.

![View from the summit](~/assets/images/hiking/south-sister-summit.jpg)

## Lessons Learned

- **Start early.** I was on the trail by 6am and glad I was. The afternoon clouds rolled in right as I was descending.
- **Poles are not optional.** The scree sections are brutal on the knees, especially on the way down.
- **Bring more water than you think.** The dry volcanic terrain and elevation combine to dehydrate you fast.
- **Layer up.** It was 70 degrees at the trailhead and felt like 35 on the summit with wind chill.

If you're in Central Oregon and haven't done this one yet, put it on the list. It's a long day, but standing on top of a volcano in your own backyard is hard to beat.

Getting Claude code to dust off the blog with a fresh start on Astro.

It's been a while.

I've had a personal site in various states of neglect for years -- Jekyll, Hugo experiments, the usual graveyard of good intentions. Today I'm starting fresh with [Astro](https://astro.build), and this time the goal is simple: just write.

I'm a software developer in Bend, Oregon. I've spent most of my career building things on the web, most recently with Vue and Firebase. But my interests go well beyond code. Lately I've been deep into:

- **AI and software** -- the tooling is changing fast and I want to think out loud about it
- **Healthspan** -- diet, exercise, sleep, and what the research actually says about living well for longer
- **Mental health** -- the intersection of performance, self-awareness, and just being a functional human
- **Self-actualization** -- lifelong learning, uncomfortable growth, trying to be a little better each day

Basically, I'm a nerd from the 80s who never stopped being curious. This is the space where I'll share what I'm learning, building, and thinking about.

If any of that resonates, welcome aboard. More to come.

A fall hike to Broken Hand from Tam McArthur Rim with Poppy and Gizmo.

One of the best things about living in Bend is having trails like this in the backyard. On September 23rd I loaded up Poppy and Gizmo and headed out to the Tam McArthur trailhead for a hike up to Broken Hand.

![Poppy and Gizmo ready to hit the trail](~/assets/images/hiking/broken-hand-trailhead.jpg)

## The Trailhead

The Tam McArthur trailhead sits at about 6,400 feet and is the jumping-off point for some of the best views in the Three Sisters Wilderness. Parking can fill up on weekends, but a Tuesday in late September meant we practically had the place to ourselves.

## The Hike Up

The trail climbs steadily through the forest before opening up to the alpine terrain that makes this area so striking. Broken Top dominates the skyline to the west, and the closer you get to Broken Hand, the more dramatic the volcanic geology becomes. Loose scree, jagged ridgelines, and views that just keep expanding.

![Views opening up along the ridge](~/assets/images/hiking/broken-hand-ridge.jpg)

Poppy led the charge the entire way, nose down and tail up. Gizmo took a more measured approach -- sniffing every rock, checking every switchback twice. Between the two of them, morale was never an issue.

![Poppy and Gizmo on the trail](~/assets/images/hiking/broken-hand-dogs-trail.jpg)

## Broken Hand

The final stretch to Broken Hand is steep and rugged. The dogs handled it better than most humans would -- sure-footed and completely unbothered by the exposure. At the top, you're rewarded with sweeping views of Broken Top's crater, the Three Sisters, and the high desert stretching east toward Bend.

![At Broken Hand with Broken Top in the background](~/assets/images/hiking/broken-hand-summit.jpg)

We hung out at the top for a while. The dogs drank water, I ate a sandwich, and we all just sat there taking it in. Late September light in the Cascades is hard to beat.

![Poppy and Gizmo resting at the top](~/assets/images/hiking/broken-hand-dogs-summit.jpg)

## Dogs on the Trail

A few notes for anyone thinking about bringing their dogs up here:

- **Bring plenty of water.** There's not much available on the trail, and dogs burn through it fast at elevation.
- **Watch the scree.** The loose volcanic rock can be rough on paws. Check them regularly.
- **Leash up where required.** The Three Sisters Wilderness has leash regulations in certain areas -- know before you go.
- **Start early.** The dogs will be happier in cooler temps, and so will you.

Poppy and Gizmo slept the entire drive home. A good sign.

A quick backpacking trip into the Mt. Jefferson Wilderness with my daughter Lily.

Some of the best trips aren't the longest ones. In early September, my daughter Lily and I packed up for an overnight at Cabot Lake in the Mt. Jefferson Wilderness. Short hike in, one night under the stars (and the clouds), and back out the next day. Sometimes that's all you need.

![Packs loaded and ready to go](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-trailhead.jpg)

## The Hike In

The trail to Cabot Lake is short enough that you're not suffering under a full pack for long. That's a nice feature when you're carrying overnight gear -- you spend less time grinding and more time actually being out there. The forest is dense and green, classic Mt. Jefferson Wilderness, with the kind of quiet that makes you forget there's a highway an hour behind you.

![Trail through the forest toward Cabot Lake](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-trail.jpg)

## Camp

We found a solid spot near the lake and set up camp. Cabot Lake is small and tucked in, surrounded by trees with Jefferson looming in the distance. It's the kind of place that feels more remote than it is. Lily and I got the tent up, filtered some water, and settled in.

![Camp set up near the lake](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-camp.jpg)

![Cabot Lake in the evening light](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-evening.jpg)

## The Thunder

And then the storms rolled in. Thunder echoing off the ridgelines, lightning flickering through the trees, rain hammering the tent fly. There's something about a thunderstorm in the backcountry that makes you feel very small and very awake at the same time. We rode it out from inside the tent, listening to the whole show.

It passed, came back, passed again. Not exactly restful sleep, but the kind of night you remember.

![Storm clouds building over the lake](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-storm.jpg)

## Morning

By morning the sky had cleared and the lake was glassy. We made coffee, packed up slow, and hiked out. No rush. That's the whole point of a one-nighter like this -- you're not trying to cover miles or bag a peak. You're just out there.

![Morning at Cabot Lake](~/assets/images/hiking/cabot-lake-morning.jpg)

It was a good trip. Twenty years old and Lily still wants to go backpacking with her dad. I'll take every one of these I can get.
